componenttext: If what's -- I want to make sure I understand, Dan. The plan that looks like it's going to come out is an Integrated Resource Plan. The process that's used today is at the state, which I give the governor a lot of credit for this. What he is doing is trying to develop the best plan possible for Michigan, and he is coordinating a lot of departments to work on this at the front end. So there's no surprises at the back end. What the legislation will do, we expect, is to support the Integrated Resource Plan. And what I mean by that is to hit the Clean Power Plan target. If we need to produce more renewable energy or more energy through renewable energy or have energy efficiency, that will be all included in this plan. Now the good news about the law, the way it is today, at least, is not the law, but the bills that are there, is that, that would allow us to go forward and have our capital plans approved to meet the Integrated Resource Plan. And that's the assurance we want, that as we go forward to meet the plan for the Clean Power Plan, which is a federal law, that the state law and the regulation supports us meeting that target. And I think as you know, many of the laws, some of the regulations that EPA has come up with, have been overturned at the last minute. But we don't want that to affect our investments and whether it's the right choice. So the pre-approval process is important to us.

componenttext: So an easy way to see that is Slide 17, the one that says "O&M cost performance." And that, mixed with the other things we have over the next 5 years, keeps us in a position where we could grow as high as 7%. And our customer rates would still be at or below inflation, which we're guessing at roughly 2%. So that gives you some of the math that you can work with. I hope that helps.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: First question, just to elaborate on the O&M conversation you were just having. These other ideas on Slide 18, roughly $50 million to $80 million of additional cost savings. headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. If you look at them in the categories that we laid them out, the 2-way communications, as we called it, which is more mobility, that's something that's going in place now. But you've got to have your systems well coordinated to make that work. So I'
componenttext: Sure. If you look at them in the categories that we laid them out, the 2-way communications, as we called it, which is more mobility, that's something that's going in place now. But you've got to have your systems well coordinated to make that work. So I'll give you an idea around that. Smart meters, in over the next year; and two, we'll have most of our smart meters in, and with that will come some mobility plus. So that's sort of a time frame where you might see that kind of thing happen. On the grid modernization, I'd push that out a little bit further, because that's better data, better line sensors, better smart meters. So I would go out several years before I would think of that as an opportunity. So you've got one, couple of years from now. Another one, maybe 5 years from now. And then, go down to work management. Now that's one where we'll actually get improvements every month, every quarter, every year, and it'll start slow. It's this simple. I always tell people, when you're changing your process, try this yourself. If you drive a car and you back out of a driveway, and you try to back out and turn the opposite direction of what you normally do, it is very hard to do. I guarantee, if you try to do that over the course of one week, you're going to be wrong at least a couple of times during that week. So it takes a lot of discipline, a lot of work, and then a lot of practice to make these things happen. Plus, we need some better systems for our work management, and that's going to take us some time to put in place. So I'd say, you'll see gradual bits of that come in over next year. Small amounts, and then a little bit more than next year. And during the life of 5 years, I think you'll see a lot of that begin to happen. So I'd call that one over 5 years. I'd call technology or the line loss past 5 years, and communication something over the 5-year period. And keep in mind, some of these will end up blending right into our plans. They'll actually be some of the cost reductions we're talking about. But a lot of these will be incremental, and that's a nice place to be.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Next question is the 5-year plan, obviously, 5% to 7% growth. In the past few slide decks have showed there's upside opportunity of 6% to 8%. Is that something that by year end, if the Michigan Energy Law goes the way that you're hoping and ROA retu
componenttext: Okay. Next question is the 5-year plan, obviously, 5% to 7% growth. In the past few slide decks have showed there's upside opportunity of 6% to 8%. Is that something that by year end, if the Michigan Energy Law goes the way that you're hoping and ROA returns, you might make that change sooner rather than later? I know it's a question you get pretty often in a bunch of different ways, but trying to get a sense of how soon that 6% to 8% might become a target. Would it -- whether it be early in the new year, or not until we have a better sense of the nuclear contract, or however, you can help frame up the timing.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me start, and then, Tom, you may want to pile on this one a little bit. Let me just go back and say again, we're very comfortable with our 5% to 7% growth rate. And what's helped us is, we really balanced the financial performance for investors w
componenttext: Yes, let me start, and then, Tom, you may want to pile on this one a little bit. Let me just go back and say again, we're very comfortable with our 5% to 7% growth rate. And what's helped us is, we really balanced the financial performance for investors with the customer value that they get. So what we're constantly doing is looking at the financial, the operational and the customer side of this business. We think today, for the next several years, there's more opportunity to invest, and I'm talking not only about capital, but O&M, back into customer value and back into operations, just as Tom talked about in the previous question. Here are the truck rolls and some of the things that we need to improve on. That's where, I think, for the next few years we really need to continue to invest and continue to grow at 5% to 7%, which is higher than our peers. What would cause this to change, I think, as Tom said in the slide that's up there right now, you can see if the law goes into effect -- and Tom made a good point I want to emphasize. If the law goes into effect as we expect and there's shortages of capacity in Michigan, which we expect in the future, customers will return to us. But it's not going to happen overnight. And it's going to take time. So we will roll that in as we go forward. But if you looked at that in the future, if the customers' satisfaction continues to be first quartile and the operations continue to be in best-in-class, then there may be a few catalysts that Tom talked about in the out years that would drive us to that. And you saw it there. The PPAs are long term. The retail open access is shorter term than the PPA need to replace those. But that's where I think you ought to think about for us. I mean, our plan is pretty good that we have here today, and there's upsides which we wanted to show you. But right now, we don't want to commit to those yet, because there's more work to do in the base business that we have.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I'll just add, the real purpose of the slide we show where it says we self fund a lot of the growth for our customers and their rates, is when we're talking about the upside opportunity. We're trying to demonstrate, short term, if ROA customers came ba
componenttext: So I'll just add, the real purpose of the slide we show where it says we self fund a lot of the growth for our customers and their rates, is when we're talking about the upside opportunity. We're trying to demonstrate, short term, if ROA customers came back; and longer term, when we might need to replace those PPAs and we could build gas plants or put in wind farms cheaper than the PPAs. Those are opportunities that we could put in place. And by the way, there were -- those things, I just said, as much as $3 billion. But those are opportunities we could do without hurting the self-funding part, without causing our customers to have bills going up any higher. So that's really the illustration there. Conversations about where we might go beyond 5% to 7%, I think, are something for the future. But we want you to know, we wouldn't go there if we couldn't take care of our customers at the same time.

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then lastly, on the long-term load growth, you talked about planning for 0.5%. Is that based on the current Michigan Energy Law? Or is that embedding an anticipation of higher energy efficiency when this law gets revamped between now and year end?
componenttext: Okay. Then lastly, on the long-term load growth, you talked about planning for 0.5%. Is that based on the current Michigan Energy Law? Or is that embedding an anticipation of higher energy efficiency when this law gets revamped between now and year end?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it could be both. But what we assume in our numbers now is that we would have about a 1% energy efficiency deduct from the economic growth. And when I say it could be both, the other thing that's not in our numbers is a heavy hand on economic develo
componenttext: Well, it could be both. But what we assume in our numbers now is that we would have about a 1% energy efficiency deduct from the economic growth. And when I say it could be both, the other thing that's not in our numbers is a heavy hand on economic development where we're beginning to see a lot of progress now. So as economic development brings in more customers, spreads that base, there could be room for energy efficiency to go up and be even higher, and still get these numbers that we're talking about. So I think we've got you in the right ballpark whatever happens.

componenttext: Yes, it is. Thetford is an existing site that we have. It has gas infrastructure, has electric infrastructure in place. componenttext: I think generally, we're -- everybody agrees with -- start with retail open access, we have to do something about it because there's an unfair subsidy. What we do about it is the debate. Is it 10% with the queue? Is it full regulation, which -- we're moving away from full regulation, more to keeping the 10% with probably a one-way door. So if you return, you'll stay with the utility. The Integrated Resource Plan is a bit of a debate because what the governor is trying to do is put in a plan that meets the EPA Clean Power Plan that also is best for Michigan. While at the same time I think some of the Democrats in the House and Senate want to have a standard in there that they can count on to that -- that will be part of the law, regardless of what happens with the Integrated Resource Plan. So that's a debate right now. The commonality, I think we've talked about this in the past, from a regulatory standpoint, self implementation will probably go away, but the -- we'll advance the timing of rate cases from 12 months to 10 months. And if they're not then in 10 months, you go into full implementation. It doesn't -- there really is...

componenttext: So the way it's structured in there, it's optionality. It's so that if a utility wanted to ask the Public Service Commission for decoupling, then they could do that. componenttext: No, we don't see any issues there. I think the filings and things they're doing with FERC to move along and keep the plant running successfully appear to be all going well. headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: And then lastly, Tom, you said you prefund 2 years in advance. Is that just interest rate hedges? Or can you elaborate on the process?

headline: CMS Energy Corp., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, what we -- we're so chicken. We are unbelievable. We have -- just because we got frightened in 2002, we never let go of this idea that we just want to be conservative when it comes to the financials side of the business. So for the parent, we actually
componenttext: No, what we -- we're so chicken. We are unbelievable. We have -- just because we got frightened in 2002, we never let go of this idea that we just want to be conservative when it comes to the financials side of the business. So for the parent, we actually reach out for 2 years. And we don't necessarily take the debt out, but we raise the debt so that the cash is in place. We don't do it with arbitrage or hedging or anything like that. We literally raise the cash. You're going to say, "What kind of conservative people are you?" but we are. So we raise it, we put that in place, and then, when the economics are right to actually call the debt and take it out, we do that. So we have the resources ready to go for 2 years out in time. And it's just that simple. There's no magic to it.

componenttext: Do mean how much cash? You know what, this is really easy to do, because we give you our maturity schedule on the parent and the utility. Just look at that, and look forward. So there's -- and you can watch that all the time, as we move through time, depending on the size of the maturities. We like being chicken, by the way.
